SENT.plain: A 7-year-old girl was admitted because of dyspnea on exertion and palpitations
Her symptoms had gradually worsened for the last 6 months
She had physical features of the Marfan syndrome
Transthoracic echocardiography showed an ascending aortic aneurysm, severe aortic regurgitation, and mildly dilated left ventricle
Because of marked aortic aneurysm and severe aortic regurgitation, the patient was treated with a beta-blocker and an angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor
Surgery was refused by her parents

We describe here a child with Marfan syndrome in whom significant dilatation of the ascending aorta and severe aortic regurgitation is encountered and major cardiovascular complications of Marfan syndrome were reviewed
